paragraphs.text:
%md

## Flink Streaming and Kafka Integration Demo

**In this example, we'll use the Flink technology in streaming mode- to read some transactions from the Berka Dataset from a kafka input topic, enrich them a little and write them to a kafka output topic**

*A first python program (A) - paragraph 3 - will send transactions read them from ElasticSearch to the input kafka topic. In addition, It will also read the result from the kafka output topic and dump these results on the console*
*Then a  second program (B) - paragraph 5 - implemented using Flink will enrich these transactions read from the input kafka topic and send the result back to the output kafka topic*
*The first program (A) finally takes care of dumping these results to the console*


```
            ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
            ┃                     ┃       ┃ I  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ O  ┃     ┃                     ┃
┏━━━━┓      ┃      Program A      ┃       ┃ N  ┃     ┃     Program B       ┃       ┃ U  ┃     ┃      Program A      ┃
┃ ES ┃─────▶┃    Populate kafka   ┃──────▶┃ P  ┃────▶┃   Flink Streaming   ┃──────▶┃ T  ┃────▶┃   Dump on console   ┃
┗━━━━┛      ┃     Input topic     ┃       ┃ U  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ P  ┃     ┃                     ┃
            ┃                     ┃       ┃ T  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ .  ┃     ┃                     ┃
            ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛       ┗━━━━┛     ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛       ┗━━━━┛     ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
Index:              Python                Topic:             Flink                  Topic:
berka-payments       Job             berka-payments          Job           berka-payments-aggregate
```

**Important Notes - READ CAREFULLY** :

* **Two sample notebooks must have been executed in prior to executing this one : the "Logstash Demo" and "Spark Integration ES", in this order**
* **The kafka topics shall better be created in advance using the following commands on one node of the cluster where kafka is available:**

```bash
echo " -- Creating KAFKA topic berka-payments"
/usr/local/bin/kafka-topics.sh \
    --create \
    --replication-factor 1 \
    --partitions 4 \
    --zookeeper {{ZOOKEEPER_SERVER}}:2181 \
    --topic berka-payments


echo " -- Creating KAFKA topic berka-profiled-aggregate"
/usr/local/bin/kafka-topics.sh \
    --create \
    --replication-factor 1 \
    --partitions 4 \
    --zookeeper {{ZOOKEEPER_SERVER}}:2181 \
    --topic berka-payments-aggregate
```

* *one needs to change the marker {{ZOOKEEPER_SERVER}} with the IP of the node running Zookeeper*

msg.data:
Flink Streaming and Kafka Integration Demo

In this example, we’ll use the Flink technology in streaming mode- to read some transactions from the Berka Dataset from a kafka input topic, enrich them a little and write them to a kafka output topic

A first python program (A) - paragraph 3 - will send transactions read them from ElasticSearch to the input kafka topic. In addition, It will also read the result from the kafka output topic and dump these results on the console
Then a second program (B) - paragraph 5 - implemented using Flink will enrich these transactions read from the input kafka topic and send the result back to the output kafka topic
The first program (A) finally takes care of dumping these results to the console

            ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
            ┃                     ┃       ┃ I  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ O  ┃     ┃                     ┃
┏━━━━┓      ┃      Program A      ┃       ┃ N  ┃     ┃     Program B       ┃       ┃ U  ┃     ┃      Program A      ┃
┃ ES ┃─────▶┃    Populate kafka   ┃──────▶┃ P  ┃────▶┃   Flink Streaming   ┃──────▶┃ T  ┃────▶┃   Dump on console   ┃
┗━━━━┛      ┃     Input topic     ┃       ┃ U  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ P  ┃     ┃                     ┃
            ┃                     ┃       ┃ T  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ .  ┃     ┃                     ┃
            ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛       ┗━━━━┛     ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛       ┗━━━━┛     ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
Index:              Python                Topic:             Flink                  Topic:
berka-payments       Job             berka-payments          Job           berka-payments-aggregate

Important Notes - READ CAREFULLY :

  • Two sample notebooks must have been executed in prior to executing this one : the “Logstash Demo” and “Spark Integration ES”, in this order
  • The kafka topics shall better be created in advance using the following commands on one node of the cluster where kafka is available:
echo " -- Creating KAFKA topic berka-payments"
/usr/local/bin/kafka-topics.sh \
    --create \
    --replication-factor 1 \
    --partitions 4 \
    --zookeeper {{ZOOKEEPER_SERVER}}:2181 \
    --topic berka-payments


echo " -- Creating KAFKA topic berka-profiled-aggregate"
/usr/local/bin/kafka-topics.sh \
    --create \
    --replication-factor 1 \
    --partitions 4 \
    --zookeeper {{ZOOKEEPER_SERVER}}:2181 \
    --topic berka-payments-aggregate
  • one needs to change the marker {{ZOOKEEPER_SERVER}} with the IP of the node running Zookeeper

paragraphs.text:
%md

### A) First program : reading Data from berka-payments index and periodically sending it to kafka input topic while also dumping on the console whatever comes on the kafka output topic

This first python program generates the input transactions by reading them from ElasticSearch. It takes care of sending these input transactions to the input kafka topic and also to read the results from the kafka output topic and dump these results on the console.

**Important Notes**:

* **The dataset used from ElasticSearch is the dataset computed by the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook**
* *The Kafka bootstrap server is extracted from the Eskimo topology (variable SELF_IP_ADDRESS gives external IP Address and then SELF_MASTER_KAFKA_XXX gives kafka server to use)*
* **The constant `ELASTICSEARCH_SERVER` shall be redefined to point on one (or many) of your nodes running Kafka, respectively to one of your node running elasticsearch**
* In order to stop this program, just cancel it's execution using the pause icon on the top right corner of the paragraph.

msg.data:
A) First program : reading Data from berka-payments index and periodically sending it to kafka input topic while also dumping on the console whatever comes on the kafka output topic

This first python program generates the input transactions by reading them from ElasticSearch. It takes care of sending these input transactions to the input kafka topic and also to read the results from the kafka output topic and dump these results on the console.

Important Notes:

  • The dataset used from ElasticSearch is the dataset computed by the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook
  • The Kafka bootstrap server is extracted from the Eskimo topology (variable SELF_IP_ADDRESS gives external IP Address and then SELF_MASTER_KAFKA_XXX gives kafka server to use)
  • The constant ELASTICSEARCH_SERVER shall be redefined to point on one (or many) of your nodes running Kafka, respectively to one of your node running elasticsearch
  • In order to stop this program, just cancel it’s execution using the pause icon on the top right corner of the paragraph.

paragraphs.text:
%python

from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch
import time, requests, json, sys, threading
from threading import Thread, Lock
from kafka import KafkaProducer, KafkaConsumer
from kafka.errors import KafkaError
import os, signal, sys

# Extract SELF IP from Eskimo Topology (env var)
selfIp = os.environ['SELF_IP_ADDRESS'].replace(".", "")

# Extract KAFKA Master IP Address
kafkaMasterIp = os.environ['SELF_MASTER_KAFKA_' + selfIp]


KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVER = [kafkaMasterIp + ":9092"]

ELASTICSEARCH_SERVER="localhost"

run = True

def handler(signum, frame):
  print("Received Signal: %d"%signum)
  run = False
  sys.exit (0);

def connect_kafka_producer():
    _producer = None
    try:
        _producer = KafkaProducer(bootstrap_servers=KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVER, api_version=(0, 10, 1))
    except Exception as ex:
        print('Exception while connecting Kafka')
        print(ex)
        sys.exit (-1);
    finally:
        return _producer

def connect_kafka_consumer():
    _consumer = None
    try:
        _consumer = KafkaConsumer(bootstrap_servers=KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVER,
                         auto_offset_reset='latest',
                         consumer_timeout_ms=3600000)
    except Exception as ex:
        print('Exception while connecting Kafka')
        print(ex)
        sys.exit (-1);
    finally:
        return _consumer


# Cache reader class thread
class ReaderClass(threading.Thread):
    def __init__(self):
        threading.Thread.__init__(self)
        self.event = threading.Event()
        self.consumer = connect_kafka_consumer()
        self.consumer.subscribe(['berka-payments-aggregate'])

    def run(self):
        for message in self.consumer:
            if self.event.is_set():
                if self.consumer is not None:
                    self.consumer.close()
                break
            event = json.loads (message.value)
            print (json.dumps (event))

    def stop(self):
        self.event.set()

def publish_message(producer_instance, topic_name, key, value):
    try:
        key_bytes = key.encode ('utf-8')
        value_bytes = value.encode ('utf-8')
        #print('sending')
        producer_instance.send(topic_name, key=key_bytes, value=value_bytes)
        #print('flushing')
        producer_instance.flush()
        #print('Message published successfully.')
    except Exception as ex:
        print('Exception in publishing message')
        print ex  
        sys.exit (-1);


es = Elasticsearch([{'host': ELASTICSEARCH_SERVER, 'port': 9200}])

kafka_producer = connect_kafka_producer()

# Launch reader thread
reader = ReaderClass()
reader.start()


res = es.search(index="berka-payments", body={"query": {"match_all": {}}}, scroll='15m', search_type='query_then_fetch', size=10000)

print("%d documents found - %d fetchable" % (res['hits']['total']['value'], len(res['hits']['hits'])) )

sid = res['_scroll_id']
scroll_size = res['hits']['total']['value']

counter = 0
print ("Sending payments to kafka ...")

# Start scrolling
while (scroll_size > 0 and run):

    page = es.scroll(scroll_id=sid, scroll='2m')

    # Update the scroll ID
    sid = page['_scroll_id']

    # Get the number of results that we returned in the last scroll
    scroll_size = len(page['hits']['hits'])

    for cur in page["hits"]["hits"]:
        
        if not run:
            sys.exit(0)
            
        data = cur["_source"]

        publish_message(kafka_producer, 'berka-payments', data['trans_id'], json.dumps(data))

        #print("(%s) - %s" % (data['trans_id'], json.dumps(data)))

        if counter % 10 == 0: 
            print ("Sent %d payments. waiting 2 seconds" % counter)
            time.sleep(2) 

        counter = counter + 1 

if kafka_producer is not None:
    kafka_producer.close()
    
time.sleep(8)     

if reader is not None:
    reader.stop()

%md

### B) Flink Streaming Program : reading from kafka input topic, computing aggregate and sending result to kafka output topic

This Flink Streaming programs reads some transactions from the Berka Dataset (resulting from the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook) from a kafka input topic as sent by the program A above. It then enriches them slightly and sends them back to a kafka output topic. The program above then dumps the resulting (enriched) transactions to the console.

**Notes**:

* *The Kafka bootstrap server is extracted from the Eskimo topology (variable SELF_IP_ADDRESS gives external IP Address and then SELF_MASTER_KAFKA_XXX gives kafka server to use)*

msg.data:
B) Flink Streaming Program : reading from kafka input topic, computing aggregate and sending result to kafka output topic

This Flink Streaming programs reads some transactions from the Berka Dataset (resulting from the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook) from a kafka input topic as sent by the program A above. It then enriches them slightly and sends them back to a kafka output topic. The program above then dumps the resulting (enriched) transactions to the console.

Notes:

  • The Kafka bootstrap server is extracted from the Eskimo topology (variable SELF_IP_ADDRESS gives external IP Address and then SELF_MASTER_KAFKA_XXX gives kafka server to use)

#### Congrats ! You ran a flink streaming program reading from and writing to kafka
